question: Question 1 A random variable X has probability density function f(x) as given below: [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} a+bx & for \; 0 \lt x \lt 1\\ 0& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] If the expected value E[X]=2/3, then [latex]Pr[X \lt 0.5][/latex] is _____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} a+bx & \text{for }0 \lt x \lt 1\\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.&\\ \text{Now given }E(X)&=2/3\\ \int_{0}^{1}xf(x)dx&=\frac{2}{3}\\ \int_{0}^{1}x(a+bx)dx&=\frac{2}{3}\\ a\left ( \frac{x^2}{2} \right )_0^1+b\left ( \frac{x^3}{3} \right )_0^1&=\frac{2}{3}\\ a\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )+b\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )&=\frac{2}{3}\\ 3a+2b&=4\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Now, }\int_{0}^{1}f(x)dx &=1\\ (\text{total probability} & \text{ is always equal to 1})\\ \int_{0}^{1}(a+bx)dx&=\left ( ax+\frac{bx^2}{2} \right )_0^1=1\\ a+\frac{b}{2}&=1\\ 2a+b&=2\;\;...(ii)\\ \text{Now solving } & \text{ (i) and (ii), we get}\\ a&=0,b=2\\ So,\; \;f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2x & \text{for }0 \lt x lt 1\\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.&\\ \text{Now we need}&\\ P(x \lt 0.5)&=\int_{0}^{0.5}2xdx=2\left ( \frac{x^2}{2} \right )_0^{0.5}\\ &=0.5^2-0^2=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 If a continuous function f(x) does not have a root in the interval [a,b], then which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Intermediate value theorem states that if a function is continious and [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \lt 0[/latex], then surely there is a root in (a,b). The contrapositive of this theorem is that if a function is continious and has no root in (a,b) then surely [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \geq 0[/latex]. But since it is given that there is no root in the closed interval [a,b] it means [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \neq 0[/latex]. So surely [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \gt 0[/latex] which is choise(C).

question: Question 3 If the sum of the diagonal elements of a 2x2 matrix is -6, then the maximum possible value of determinant of the matrix is ________.
solution: Consider a symmetric matrix [latex]A =\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ b & d \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Given [latex]a+d=-6[/latex] [latex]|A|=ad-b^2[/latex] Now since [latex]b^2[/latex] is always non-negative, maximum determinant will come when [latex]b^2=0[/latex]. So we need to maximize [latex]\begin{aligned} |A|&=ad-0=ad=a \times -(6+a) \\ &= -a^2-6a\\ \frac{d|A|}{da} &=-2a-6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; a &=-3 \text{ is the only stationary point} \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, [latex]\left [\frac{d^2|A|}{da} \right ]_{a=-3}=-2 \lt 0[/latex], we have a maximum at [latex]a=-3[/latex]. Since [latex]a+d=-6[/latex], corresponding value of [latex]d=-3[/latex]. [latex]|A|=ad=-3 \times -3=9[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider a function [latex]\vec{f}=\frac{1}{r^{2}}\hat{r}[/latex], where r is the distance from the origin and [latex]\hat{r}[/latex] is the unit vector in the radial direction. The divergence of this function over a sphere of radius R, which includes the origin, is
solution: [latex]\bar{f}=\frac{1}{r^2}\hat{r} [/latex] From divergence theorem as we know, [latex]\begin{aligned} \int _{vol.} (\triangledown \cdot \bar{f})dV &=\oint \oint _S \bar{f}\cdot d\bar{S}\\ \oint \oint _S \bar{f}\cdot d\bar{S} &= \oint \oint _S \left ( \frac{1}{r^2} \cdot \hat{r}\right ) \times r^2 \sin \theta \cdot d\theta \cdot d\phi \cdot \hat{r} \\ &= \oint \oint _S \sin \theta \cdot d\theta \cdot d\phi=4\pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 When the Wheatstone bridge shown in the figure is used to find the value of resistor [latex]R_X[/latex], the galvanometer G indicates zero current when [latex]R_1=50\Omega ,R_2=65\Omega[/latex] and [latex]R_3=100\Omega[/latex]. If [latex]R_3[/latex] is known with [latex]\pm 5[/latex]% tolerance on its nominal value of 100 [latex]\Omega[/latex] , what is the range of [latex]R_X[/latex] in Ohms?
solution: [latex]R_1=50\Omega [/latex] [latex]R_2=60\Omega [/latex] [latex] R_3=100\pm 5%\Omega [/latex] The value of [latex]R_3 \text{with} \pm 5[/latex]%  of tollerance, [latex]\begin{aligned} R_3&= 100\pm 5\% \\ &= 100+100 \times \frac{5}{100}=105 \Omega \\ &= 100-100 \times \frac{5}{100}=95 \Omega \end{aligned} [/latex] In both condition, the bridge is balance, so under balance condition, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{R_1}{R_3}&=\frac{R_2}{R_x} \\ R_x&=\frac{R_2R_3}{R_1} \\ (i) \; \text{when}, \; R_3&=105\Omega \\ \therefore \;\;R_x &= \frac{105 \times 65}{50}=136.50\Omega \\ (ii)\; \text{when}, \; R_3&=95 \Omega \\ \therefore \;\;R_x &= \frac{95 \times 65}{50}=123.50\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 A (0-50 A) moving coil ammeter has a voltage drop of 0.1 V across its terminals at full scale deflection. The external shunt resistance (in milliohms) needed to extend its range to (0-500 A) is _______.
solution: [latex]I_{fs}=50A, [/latex] [latex]V_m=0.1V, [/latex] [latex]R_m=\frac{0.1}{50}=2 \times 10^{-3}\Omega [/latex] [latex]\because \; m=10 [/latex] [latex]R_{sh}=\frac{R_m}{(m-1)}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{2 \times 10^{-3}}{9}=0.22\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 7 Of the four characteristics given below, which are the major requirements for an instrumentation amplifier? P. High common mode rejection ratio Q. High input impedance R. High linearity S. High output impedance

Question 8 In the following chopper, the duty ratio of switch S is 0.4. If the inductor and capacitor are sufficiently large to ensure continuous inductor current and ripple free capacitor voltage, the charging current (in Ampere) of the 5 V battery, under steady-state, is_____.
solution: Step down chopper [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \; V_0&=\alpha V_s\\ V_0&=I_0R+E\\ I_0&=\frac{V_0-E}{R}\\ I_0&=\frac{\alpha V_s-E}{R}\\ &=\frac{(0.4)20-5}{3}=1A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 9 A moving average function is given by [latex]y(t)=\frac{1}{T}\int_{t-T}^{t}u(\tau )d\tau[/latex]. If the input u is a sinusoidal signal of frequency [latex]\frac{1}{2\tau }[/latex] Hz, then in steady state, the output y will lag u (in degree) by ______ .
solution:
System input: [latex]\sin \omega _0 t[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
f_0&=\frac{1}{2T}Hz\\
\text{Therefore,}\\
\omega _0&=2 \pi f_0=\frac{2 \pi}{2T}=\frac{\pi}{T}\; rad/sec\\
y(t)&=\frac{1}{T}\int_{t-T}^{t}\sin \omega _0\tau \; d\tau\\
&=\frac{1}{T}[-\cos\omega _0 t ]_{t-T}^t\\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t -\cos\omega _0 (t-T) ]\\
&\left [ \because \; \omega _0=\frac{t}{T} \right ]\\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t -\cos\left ( \frac{\pi t}{T}- \pi \right ) ]\\ \\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t +\cos\omega _0 t ]\\
&=-\frac{2}{T} \cos\omega _0 t \\
&=\frac{2}{T}\sin (\omega _0 t -90^{\circ}) \\
&=\text{Output is lagging by }90^{\circ} \text{ w.r.t. input.}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 10 The impulse response g(t) of a system, G , is as shown in Figure (a). What is the maximum value attained by the impulse response of two cascaded blocks of G as shown in Figure (b)?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g(t)&=u(t)-u(t-1)\\ G(s)&=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-s}}{s}\\ G(s) \times G(s)&=g(t)* g(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum value =1

question: Question 11 Consider a one-turn rectangular loop of wire placed in a uniform magnetic field as shown in the figure. The plane of the loop is perpendicular to the field lines. The resistance of the loop is 0.4 [latex]\Omega[/latex], and its inductance is negligible. The magnetic flux density (in Tesla) is a function of time, and is given by [latex]B(t)=0.25 \sin \omega t, [/latex] where [latex]  \omega =2\pi \times 50[/latex] radian/second. The power absorbed (in Watt) by the loop from the magnetic field is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A&=10cm \times 5 cm\\ B(t)&=0.25 \sin \omega t,\; R=0.4\Omega \\ P&=i^2 R\\ \because \; e&=-\frac{d\phi }{dt}=-\frac{d}{dt}(B \times A)\\ &=-\frac{d}{dt}[0.25 \times 50 \times 10^{-4} \sin \omega t]\\ e&=-0.25 \times 50 \times 10^4 \omega \cos \omega t\\ &=-1.25 \times 10^{-3}\omega \cos \omega t\\ P_{evg}&=\frac{e^2_{rms}}{R}\\ P&=\int_{0}^{T}\frac{(12.5 \times 100 \pi \times 10^{-4})^2}{0.4} \times \cos ^2 \omega t d(\omega t)\\ &=(12.5 \times \pi \times 10^{-2})^2 \times \frac{1}{2 \times 0.4}\\ &=0.193\; \text{Watt} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 A steady current I is flowing in the -x direction through each of two infinitely long wires at [latex]y=\pm \frac{L}{2}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The permeability of the medium is [latex]\mu _{0}[/latex]. The [latex]\vec{B}[/latex]-field at (0,L,0) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{B}&=\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi \left ( \frac{L}{2} \right )}(-\hat{z})+\frac{\mu _0 I}{2\pi \left ( \frac{3L}{2} \right )}(-\hat{z}) \\ &=\frac{\mu _0 I(-\hat{z})}{2\pi L}\left ( 2+\frac{2}{3} \right )\\ &=-\frac{4}{3}\frac{\mu _0 I}{\pi L}\hat{z} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 Consider the circuit shown in the figure. In this circuit R=1k[latex]\Omega[/latex], and C=1[latex]\mu[/latex]F. The input voltage is sinusoidal with a frequency of 50 Hz, represented as a phasor with magnitude [latex]V_i[/latex] and phase angle 0 radian as shown in the figure. The output voltage is represented as a phasor with magnitude [latex]V_o[/latex] and phase angle [latex]\delta[/latex] radian. What is the value of the output phase angle [latex]\delta[/latex] (in radian) relative to the phase angle of the input voltage?
solution: The circuit is Since circuit has negative feedback, so with help of virtual short [latex]V_A=V_B[/latex] So, KVL in the loop from A to B given, [latex]I\left ( \frac{1}{sC} \right )-V_i+I\left ( \frac{1}{sC} \right )=0 [/latex] So,  [latex]I=\frac{V_i(sC)}{2}[/latex] So,   [latex] V_A=-IR [/latex] [latex]V_A=-\frac{sCRV_i}{2}[/latex] and   [latex] V_A=V_B [/latex] So,   [latex]V_B=-\frac{sCRV_i}{2}[/latex] Now,   [latex] \frac{V_B-V_o}{R}=I [/latex] So,   [latex]V_o=V_B-IR [/latex] [latex]V_o=-\frac{V_i(sCR)}{2}-\frac{V_i(sCR)}{2} [/latex] [latex]\;\; =-V_i(sCR) [/latex] So,  [latex]V_o=-j\omega RCV_i[/latex] So, [latex]V_o[/latex] lag [latex]V_i[/latex] by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] or phase of  [latex]V_o[/latex] w.r.t [latex]V_i[/latex] is [latex]-90^{\circ}[/latex].

question: Question 14 In the given circuit, the silicon transistor has [latex]\beta[/latex]=75 and a collector voltage [latex]V_c[/latex]=9 V. Then the ratio of [latex]R_{B}[/latex] and [latex]R_{C}[/latex] is ________.
solution: Consider the circuit shown in figure. [latex]V_C=9V [/latex] [latex]So,\;\; \frac{15-9}{R_C}=I_E [/latex] [latex]\frac{6}{R_C}=I_E [/latex] [latex]and \;\;\frac{9-0.7}{R_B}=I_B [/latex] [latex]So,\;\;\frac{8.3}{R_B}=I_B [/latex] [latex]So, \;\; \frac{I_E}{I_B}=\frac{6 \times R_B}{R_C \times 8.3} [/latex] [latex](\beta +1)=\frac{R_B \times 6}{R_C \times 8.3}[/latex] [latex] \frac{R_B}{R_C}=105.13[/latex]

question: Question 15 In the 4 x 1 multiplexer, the output F is given by [latex]F=A\oplus B[/latex]. Find the required input '[latex]I_{3}I_{2}I_{1}I_{0}[/latex]'.
solution: [latex]F=A\oplus B [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\bar{A}B+A\bar{B} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\bar{A}\bar{B}I_0+\bar{A}BI_1+A\bar{B}I_2+ABI_3 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_0=0, I_1=1, I_2=1, i_3=0 [/latex] [latex]I_3I_2I_1I_0=0110[/latex]

question: Question 16 Consider a HVDC link which uses thyristor based line-commutated converters as shown in the figure. For a power flow of 750 MW from System 1 to System 2, the voltages at the two ends, and the current, are given by: [latex]V_{1}[/latex]=500 kV, [latex]V_{2}[/latex]=485 kV and [latex]V_{3}[/latex]=1.5 kA. If the direction of power flow is to be reversed (that is, from System 2 to System 1) without changing the electrical connections, then which one of the following combinations is feasible?
solution: To maintain the direction of power flow from system 2 to system 1, the voltage [latex]V_1=-485kV[/latex] and voltage [latex]V_2=500kV[/latex] and [latex]I=1.5kA[/latex]. Since, current cannot flow in reverse direction. Option (B) is correct answer.

question: Question 17 Base load power plants are P: wind farms. Q: run-of-river plants. R: nuclear power plants. S: diesel power plants.

Question 18 The voltages developed across the 3 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistors shown in the figure are 6 V and 2V respectively, with the polarity as marked. What is the power (in Watt) delivered by the 5V voltage source?
solution: Power =5x1=5 Watt

question: Question 19 For the given circuit, the Thevenin equivalent is to be determined. The Thevenin voltage, [latex]V_{Th}[/latex] (in Volt), seen from terminal AB is __________.
solution: [latex]2-1(i_1+i)-i=0 [/latex] [latex]2-i_1-2i=0 [/latex] [latex]2i + i_1=2\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex] \frac{V-2}{1}+\frac{V}{1}+\frac{V-(-20i)}{2}=0 [/latex] [latex]2(V-2)+2V+V+20i=0 [/latex] [latex]5V+20i=4 [/latex] where,  [latex] \frac{V}{1}=i [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 25i=4 [/latex] [latex]i=\frac{4}{25}A [/latex] [latex]i_1=2-2 \times \frac{4}{25} =1.68A [/latex] [latex]V_{AB}=1.68 \times 2=3.36 V[/latex]

question: Question 20 An inductor is connected in parallel with a capacitor as shown in the figure. As the frequency of current i is increased, the impedance (Z) of the network varies as
solution: [latex]Z=j\omega L||\frac{1}{j\omega C}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=\frac{L/C}{j\omega L+\frac{1}{j\omega C}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{(L/C)j\omega C}{-\omega ^2 LC+1} [/latex] [latex]Z=\frac{j\omega L}{1-\omega^2 LC} [/latex] [latex]|Z|=\frac{\omega L}{1-\omega^2 LC} [/latex] For,  [latex] 1\gt \omega^2 LC; [/latex] [latex]Z=+ve[/latex] For, [latex]1 \lt \omega^2 LC;[/latex] [latex] Z=-ve[/latex]

question: Question 21 A separately excited DC generator has an armature resistance of 0.1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and negligible armature inductance. At rated field current and rated rotor speed, its open-circuit voltage is 200 V. When this generator is operated at half the rated speed, with half the rated field current, an un-charged 1000 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor is suddenly connected across the armature terminals. Assume that the speed remains unchanged during the transient. At what time (in microsecond) after the capacitor is connected will the voltage across it reach 25 V?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R_a &= 0.1\Omega \\ V_{OC}&= 200V\\ I'_{f}&= \frac{I_f}{2}\\ \omega '&= \frac{\omega _{rated}}{2}\\ E_g&= k\phi \omega \\ E'_g&= k\frac{\phi }{2} \times \frac{\omega }{2}\\ &= \frac{200}{4}=50V\\ V&=V(\infty )-[V(\infty )-V(0)]e^{-t/T} \\ &= 50-[50-0]e^{-t/T} \\ 25&= 50[1-e^{-t/RC} ]\\ \frac{1}{2}&= 1-e^{-t/100 \times 10^{-6}}\\ e^{-t/10^{-4}}&= \frac{1}{2}\\ t&=0.693 \times 10^{-4}\\ &=69.3\mu s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 The self inductance of the primary winding of a single phase, 50 Hz, transformer is 800 mH, and that of the secondary winding is 600 mH. The mutual inductance between these two windings is 480 mH. The secondary winding of this transformer is short circuited and the primary winding is connected to a 50 Hz, single phase, sinusoidal voltage source. The current flowing in both the windings is less than their respective rated currents. The resistance of both windings can be neglected. In this condition, what is the effective inductance (in mH) seen by the source?
solution: Self inductance of primary coil is 500 mH. Self inductance of secondary coil is 600 mH. Mutual inductance is 480 mH. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{So,} \;\; L_1&=800mH \\ L_2&=600 mH \\ M &=480mH \end{aligned}[/latex] The voltage source [latex]V_1[/latex] is sinusoidal with frequency 50 Hz. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{So,} \;\; V_2&=L_2 \frac{dI_2}{dt}+\frac{MdI_1}{dt} \\ V_2&=0 \\ \text{So,} \;\; j\omega L_2I_2 &=-j\omega MI_1 \\ \text{So,} \;\; I_2&=-I_1 \frac{M}{L_2}=-\frac{4}{5}I_1 \\ \text{Now,} \;\; V_1&= L_1 \frac{dI_1}{dt}+\frac{MdI_2}{dt} \\ V_1 &=j\omega L_1I_1+j\omega MI_2 \\ V_1&=j\omega [L_1I_1+MI_2] \\ V_1&=j\omega [800mH-384mH]I_1 \\ \frac{V_1}{I_1}&=j\omega [416mH] \end{aligned}[/latex] So, equivalent inductance is [latex]416 mH.[/latex]

question: Question 23 The primary mmf is least affected by the secondary terminal conditions in a
Question 24 A Bode magnitude plot for the transfer function G(s) of a plant is shown in the figure. Which one of the following transfer functions best describes the plant?
solution: From initial line equation, [latex]20 dB=20log_{10}K[/latex] as we know, [latex]20 dB=20log_{10}K[/latex] [latex] K=10[/latex] now, from the given plot we know type of system is one. Hence, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+sT_1)}{(1+sT_2)} [/latex] [latex]T_1=\frac{1}{10}; \;\;T_2=\frac{1}{1000}[/latex] [latex] G(s)=\frac{10(1+0.001s)}{(1+0.1s)} =\frac{(1000+s)}{10(s+10)}[/latex]

question: Question 25 For the signal-flow graph shown in the figure, which one of the following expressions is equal to the transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X_{2}(s)}|_{X_{1}(s)=0}[/latex]?
Question 26 The maximum value of "a" such that the matrix [latex]\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 0& -2\\ 1 &-1 & 0\\ 0& a&-2 \end{pmatrix}[/latex] has three linearly independent real eigenvectors is

Question 27 A solution of the ordinary differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+5\frac{dy}{dt}+6y=0[/latex] is such that y(0)=2 and [latex]y(1)= -\frac{1-3e}{e^{3}}[/latex]. The value of [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}(0)[/latex] is _______
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
 D^2+5D+6&=0 \\ 
D &=-1,-3 \\ 
 y(t)&=c_1e^{-2t}+c_2e^{-3t} \\ 
\text{Given,  } y(0)&=2 \\ 
\Rightarrow \; c_1+c_2 &=2\;\;...(i) \\ 
 y(1)&=-\left ( \frac{1-3e}{e^3} \right ) \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\; \frac{c_1}{e^2}+\frac{c_2}{e^3} &= -\left ( \frac{1-3e}{e^3} \right ) \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\;ec_1+c_2 &=3e-1\;\;\;...(ii) \\ 
\text{Now solving equation} &\text{ (i) and (ii), we get} \\ 
c_1=3, &c_2=-1\\ 
 \text{Substituting in  }y(t),& we get \\ 
 y(t)&=3e^{-2t}-e^{-3t}\\
\text{Now,   }\frac{dy}{dt}&=-6e^{-2t}+3e^{-3t}\\
\left ( \frac{dy}{dt} \right )_{t=0}&=-6+3=-3 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 The signum function is given by [latex]sgn(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{x}{|x|}; &x\neq 0 \\ 0; & x=0 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The Fourier series expansion of sgn(cos(t)) has
solution: So, cos(t) is So, sgn(cos t) is a rectangular signal which is even and has half wave symmetry. So, Fourier series will have only cosine terms with add harmonics only.

options.A: only sine terms with all harmonics
options.B: only cosine terms with all harmonics.
options.C: only sine terms with even numbered harmonics.
options.D: only cosine terms with odd numbered harmonics.

question: Question 29 Two players, A and B, alternately keep rolling a fair dice. The person to get a six first wins the game. Given that player A starts the game, the probability that A wins the game is
solution: P(A wins) = P( 6 in first throw by A) + P(A not 6, B not 6,)+... [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{6}+\frac{5}{6}\frac{5}{6}\frac{1}{6}+....\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left ( 1+\left ( \frac{5}{6} \right )^2+\left ( \frac{5}{6} \right )^4+... \right )\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left ( \frac{1}{1-\left (\frac{5}{6} \right )^2} \right )=\frac{6}{11} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 An unbalanced DC Wheatstone bridge is shown in the figure. At what value of p will the magnitude of [latex]V_o[/latex] be maximum?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0 &= \left [ \frac{R(1+x)}{PR+R(1+x)}-\frac{R}{R+PR} \right ]E\\ V_0 &=\left [ \frac{R(1+x)}{R+(1+x+P)}-\frac{R}{R+(1+P)} \right ]E \\ V_0&= \left [ \frac{1+x}{1+x+P}-\frac{1}{1+P} \right ]E\\ V_0&=\left [ \frac{(1+x)(1+P)-(1+x+P)}{(1+x+P)(1+P)} \right ]E \\ V_0&=\left [ \frac{1+x+Px+P-1-x-P}{1+P+x+xP+P+P^2} \right ]E \\ V_0&=\left [ \frac{Px}{1+2P+P^2+x+xP} \right ]E \end{aligned}[/latex] For maximum [latex]V_0,[/latex] [latex] \frac{dV_0}{dP}=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\frac{x}{1+x+P(P+2+x)}-\frac{xP(2P+x+2)}{1+x+P(2+P+x)^2}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; [1+x+P(2+P+x)]=P(2P+x+2) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 1+x+2P+P^2+Px=2p^2+Px+2P [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 1+x=P^2[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; P=\sqrt{1+x}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The circuit shown is meant to supply a resistive load [latex]R_{L}[/latex] from two separate DC voltage sources. The switches S1 and S2 are controlled so that only one of them is ON at any instant. S1 is turned on for 0.2 ms and S2 is turned on for 0.3 ms in a 0.5 ms switching cycle time period. Assuming continuous conduction of the inductor current and negligible ripple on the capacitor voltage, the output voltage [latex]V_{0}[/latex] (in Volt) across [latex]R_{L}[/latex] is ___________.
solution: [latex]S_1[/latex] is turn ON for 0.2 ms [latex]S_2[/latex] is turn ON for 0.3 ms. Switching cycle time period is 0.5 ms. the output voltage [latex]V_0[/latex] across [latex]R_L[/latex] is [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&= \frac{1}{0.5 \times 10^{-3}}\left [ \int_{0}^{0.2}10dt +\int_{0.2}^{0.5}5 dt \right ]\\ &= \frac{1}{0.5 \times 10^{-3}} [10(0.2)+5(0.5-0.2)]\\ &=\frac{1}{0.5 \times 10^{-3}} [2 \times 10^{-3}+1.5 \times 10^{-3}] \\ &= \frac{3.5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.5 \times 10^{-3}}=7V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A self commutating switch SW, operated at duty cycle [latex]\delta[/latex] is used to control the load voltage as shown in the figure Under steady state operating conditions, the average voltage across the inductor and the capacitor respectively, are
solution: The average voltage across inductor, [latex]V_L=0[/latex] and hence the given circuit is a boost regular so average voltage across capacitor is equal to average voltage across the load so, [latex]V_0=\left ( \frac{1}{1-\delta } \right )V_{dc}[/latex]

question: Question 33 The single-phase full-bridge voltage source inverter (VSI), shown in figure, has an output frequency of 50 Hz. It uses unipolar pulse width modulation with switching frequency of 50 kHz and modulation index of 0.7. For [latex]V_{in}[/latex] =100 V DC, L=9.55 mH, C=63.66 [latex]\mu[/latex]F, and R=5 [latex]\Omega[/latex], the amplitude of the fundamental component in the output voltage [latex]V_o[/latex] (in Volt) under steady-state is ________.
solution:
The rms value of the fundamental component of output voltage, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{R1}&=\frac{V_s}{\sqrt{2}}\times m_i \\ &= \frac{100}{\sqrt{2}} \times 0.7=49.49V \end{aligned}[/latex] Amplitude of the value is peak value (i.e.) [latex]V_{R_{peak}}=\sqrt{2} \times 49.49=70V[/latex] [latex]V_{R_{peak}}[/latex] is the amplitude of fundamental voltage at the VSI. [latex]V_{0_{(peak)}}[/latex] is the amplitude of fundamental voltage at the resistor. [latex]\begin{aligned}
 Z&=\frac{R(-jX_C)}{R-X_Cj} \\ 
 &= \frac{5(-j50)}{5-j50}\\ 
 &= 4.97\angle -5.71^{\circ}\Omega \\ 
\text{where, } X_C&= \frac{1}{\omega C}\\ 
 &=\frac{1}{2 \pi \times 50 \times 63.66 \times 10^{-6}} \\ 
 &= 50\Omega \\ 
X_L &=\omega L \\ 
 &=2 \pi \times 50 \times 9.55 \times 10^{-3} \\ 
 &= 3 \Omega\\
V_{0(peak)}&=V_{R_{peak}} \times \frac{4.97\angle -5.71^{\circ}}{(4.97\angle -5.71^{\circ})+j3}\\
&=62.75\angle -32.5^{\circ}\;V
\end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, the amplitude of the fundamental component in the output voltage, [latex]V_0=62.75V[/latex]

question: Question 34 A 3-phase 50 Hz square wave (6-step) VSI feeds a 3-phase, 4 pole induction motor. The VSI line voltage has a dominant [latex]5^{th}[/latex] harmonic component. If the operating slip of the motor with respect to fundamental component voltage is 0.04, the slip of the motor with respect to [latex]5^{th}[/latex] harmonic component of voltage is _________.
solution: [latex]N_S=\frac{120f}{P}=1500[/latex] Slip due to 5th harmmonic [latex]S_5=\frac{N_S+\frac{N_s}{5}}{N_S}=\frac{6}{5}=1.2[/latex]

question: Question 35 Consider a discrete time signal given by [latex]x[n]=(-0.25)^{n}u[n]+(0.5)^{n}u[-n-1][/latex] The region of convergence of its Z-transform would be
solution: [latex]x[n]=(0.25)^nu(n)+(0.5)^n u(-n-1)[/latex] Signal [latex]x[n][/latex] is sum of two signals, one is right sided [latex][(-0.25)^n u(n)][/latex] and other is left sided [latex][(0.5)^n u(-n-1)][/latex]. The right sided signal will have pole at location with magnitude 0.25. So, ROC is [latex]|z| \gt 0.25[/latex]. The left sided signal will have pole at location with magnitude 0.5. So, ROC is [latex]|z| \lt 0.5[/latex]. So, ROC of X(z) (Z-transform of x(n) will be ) [latex]0.25 \lt |z| \lt 0.5[/latex].

options.A: the region inside the circle of radius 0.5 and centered at origin
options.B: the region outside the circle of radius 0.25 and centered at origin
options.C: the annular region between the two circles, both centered at origin and having radii 0.25 and 0.5

question: Question 36 A parallel plate capacitor is partially filled with glass of dielectric constant 4.0 as shown below. The dielectric strengths of air and glass are 30 kV/cm and 300 kV/cm, respectively. The maximum voltage (in kilovolts), which can be applied across the capacitor without any breakdown, is ______.
solution: A capacitor is made as shown in figure Breakdown of dielectric air is 30 kV/cm and breakdown of dielectric glass is 300 kV/cm. We need to find maximum value of [latex]V_{AB}[/latex] so that no [latex]C_1[/latex] or [latex]C_2[/latex] breaks down. Since, area and width of  [latex]C_1[/latex] and [latex]C_2[/latex] is same but [latex]\varepsilon _{r_1}=1[/latex] and [latex]\varepsilon _{r_2}=4[/latex] So,  [latex]C_2=4C_1[/latex] So, if [latex]V_{AB}[/latex] is applied, [latex]V_{C_1}=\frac{4}{5}V_{AB}[/latex] and [latex]V_{C_2}=\frac{1}{5}V_{AB}[/latex] For [latex]C_1[/latex] not breakdown, we need [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{4}{5}\frac{V_{AB}}{5mm}&\lt 30kV/cm \\ V_{AB}& \lt \frac{30 \times 25 \times 1000}{4}V \\ V_{A}& \lt 18.75kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The figure shows a digital circuit constructed using negative edge triggered J-K flip flops. Assume a starting state of [latex]Q_{2}Q_{1}Q_{0}=000[/latex]. This state [latex]Q_{2}Q_{1}Q_{0}=000[/latex] will repeat after _______ number of cycles of the clock CLK
solution: JK flip-flop1 and 2 from a syncgronous sequential circuits and they are synchronized with the output of 0th JK flip-flop. Number of cycles = 3 i.e. equal to 6 clock cycles.

question: Question 38 f(A,B,C,D)=[latex]\Pi[/latex]M(0,1,3,4,5,7,9,11,12,13,14,15) is a maxterm representation of a Boolean function f(A,B,C,D) where A is the MSB and D is the LSB. The equivalent minimized representation of this function is

Question 39 The op-amp shown in the figure has a finite gain A = 1000 and an infinite input resistance. A step-voltage [latex]V_{i}=1 mV[/latex] is applied at the input at time t=0 as shown. Assuming that the operational amplifier is not saturated, the time constant (in millisecond) of the output voltage [latex]V_{o}[/latex] is
solution: The circuit is Now, the gain of op-amp is 1000 So,   [latex]V_o=1000(V_+-V_-) [/latex] Since  [latex]V_+=0[/latex] (grounded) [latex] V_-=V_A[/latex] The above circuit can be redrawn as So, [latex]V_o=1000\;VA[/latex] Now, KCL at node 'A' [latex] \frac{V_A-V_i}{1000}=\left ( \frac{V_A-V_o}{1/sC} \right )[/latex] [latex] \frac{V_A-V_i}{1000}=\frac{V_A-(-1000V_A)}{1/sC} [/latex] [latex]\frac{V_A-V_i}{1000}=(1001V_A)sC [/latex] [latex]V_A-V_i=(1001)\times 1000V_AsC [/latex] [latex]V_A-V_i=s(1001000 \times 10^{-6}) V_A [/latex] [latex]V_A-s1.001V_A=V_i [/latex] [latex]V_A=\left [ \frac{V_i}{1-s(1.001)} \right ][/latex] Since,  [latex] V_o=-1000V_A [/latex] [latex]\;\; =-\frac{1000}{1-s(1.001)} V_i[/latex] Since, pole is at (1/1.001), so time constant is approax '1001'.

question: Question 40 An 8-bit, unipolar Successive Approximation Register type ADC is used to convert 3.5 V to digital equivalent output. The reference voltage is +5 V. The output of the ADC, at the end of 3rd clock pulse after the start of conversion, is
solution: The reference voltage is 5 V. The number of bits in ADC are 8. So, the resolution will be [latex]=\frac{5}{2^8-1}=\frac{5}{255}[/latex] The applied input is 3.5 V. The succesive approximation ADC start working from the MSB so, After one clock: SAR will toggle it's MSB from [latex]0\rightarrow 1[/latex]. So, output of SAR will be 1000 0000. After second clock: SAR will toggle its 7th bit from [latex]0\rightarrow 1[/latex] but 1100 0000 will result in value greater than 3.5. So, output of SAR after 2nd clock will be 1000 0000. After third clock: SAR will toggle it's 6th bit from [latex]0\rightarrow 1[/latex] and output will be 1010 0000.

question: Question 41 Consider the economic dispatch problem for a power plant having two generating units. The fuel costs in Rs/MWh along with the generation limits for the two units are given below: [latex]C_{1}(P_{1})=0.01{P_{1}}^2+30P_{1}+10[/latex];   [latex]100MW\leq P_{1} \leq 150MW[/latex] [latex]  C_{2}(P_{2})=0.05{P_{2}}^2+10P_{2}+10[/latex];  [latex]100MW\leq P_{2} \leq 180MW[/latex] The incremental cost (in Rs/MWh) of the power plant when it supplies 200 MW is ______ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_1&=0.01P_1^2+30P_1+10\\ \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=2 \times 0.01P_1+30\\ &=0.02P_1+30\\ C_2&=0.05P_2^2+10P_2+10\\ \frac{dC-2}{dP_2}&=0.1P_2+10\\ \text{For optimum } &\text{incremental cost,}\\ \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_2}\\ 0.02P_1+30&=0.1P_2+10\\ 0.02P_1-0.1P_2&=-20 \;\;...(i)\\ \text{Given, }P_1+P_2&=200 \;\;...(ii)\\ \text{Solving } & \text{equation (i) and (ii),}\\ P_2&=200, P_1=0\\ \text{But the }& \text{range of }P_1 \text{ and }P_2 \text{ are specified as}\\ 100MW \leq & P_1 \leq 150MW\\ 100MW \leq & P_2 \leq 180MW\\ \text{hence, }& P_2=200 MW \text{ is not valid}\\ \text{so, both }& P_1 \text{ and } P_2 \text{ are operating at}\\ P_1=100,P_2=100\;& \Rightarrow \; P_1+P_2=200\\ IC_1=\frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=0.02 \times P_1+30=32 Rs/MW\\ IC_2=\frac{dC_2}{dP_2}&=0.1 \times P_2+10=20 Rs/MW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion [a] and the Reason [r]. Assertion: Fast decoupled load flow method gives approximate load flow solution because it uses several assumptions. Reason: Accuracy depends on the power mismatch vector tolerance.
solution: FDLF method gives approximate solution not because it uses several assumption but due to the fixed number of iterations.

options.A: Both [a] and [r] are true and [r] is the correct reason for [a].
options.B: Both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is not the correct reason for [a].

question: Question 43 A 50 Hz generating unit has H-constant of 2 MJ/MVA. The machine is initially operating in steady state at synchronous speed, and producing 1 pu of real power. The initial value of the rotor angle [latex]\delta[/latex] is 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], when a bolted three phase to ground short circuit fault occurs at the terminal of the generator. Assuming the input mechanical power to remain at 1 pu, the value of [latex]\delta[/latex] in degrees, 0.02 second after the fault is _________.
solution:
Let [latex]3-\phi[/latex] fault occurs at t=0 [latex]\Rightarrow \; P_e=0\text{ for }t\geq 0^+[/latex] Now, swing equation for [latex]t\geq 0^+[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{2H}{\omega _s}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2} &=P_m \\ 
 \frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}\\ 
\frac{d\delta }{dt}&= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}t+C\\ 
 C=\left.\begin{matrix}
\frac{d\delta }{dt}
\end{matrix}\right| _{t=0^+}&=\omega (t=0^+)-\omega _s\\ 
 C=\omega _s-\omega _s&=0\;(\omega (t-0^+)=\omega _s) \\ 
 \frac{d\delta }{dt}&=\frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}t \\ 
 \Rightarrow \; \delta &= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{4H}t^2+C'\\ 
 C'&= \delta |_{t=0^+}=\delta _0\\ 
\delta  &= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{4H}t^2+\delta _0\\
\text{Now in problem,}\\
\delta (t=0.02)&\\
&=\frac{1 \times 2  \times 180  \times 50 \times 0.02^2 +5^{\circ}}{4 \times 2}\\
&=5.9^{\circ}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A sustained three-phase fault occurs in the power system shown in the figure. The current and voltage phasors during the fault (on a common reference), after the natural transients have died down, are also shown. Where is the fault located?
solution: From the phasor [latex]I_2[/latex] and [latex]I_4[/latex] are having [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex] phase shift. [latex]|I_1|[/latex] is higher than all other. Hence fault occurred at point Q.

question: Question 45 The circuit s hown in the figure has two sources connected in series. The instantaneous voltage of the AC source (in Volt) is given by [latex]v(t)=12\sin t[/latex]. If the circuit is in steady state, then the rms value of the current (in Ampere) flowing in the circuit is ______ .
solution: [latex]i(t)=\frac{8}{1}+\frac{12 \sin t}{\sqrt{1+1}}=8+6\sqrt{2} \sin t [/latex] [latex]i_{rms}(t)=\sqrt{8^2+\frac{1}{2}(6\sqrt{2} )^2}=10A[/latex]

question: Question 46 In a linear two-port network, when 10 V is applied to Port 1, a current of 4 A flows through Port 2 when it is short-circuited. When 5 V is applied to Port 1, a current of 1.25 A flows through a 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance connected across Port 2. When 3 V is applied to Port 1, the current (in Ampere) through a 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance connected across Port 2 is _______.
solution: [latex]V_1=10V, I_2=4 A, V_2=0\;\;Cond...(i)[/latex] [latex]V_1=5V, I_2=1.25 A,[/latex]  [latex] V_2=1.25 \times 1=1.25V\;\;Cond...(ii)[/latex] [latex] V_1=3V, I_2=? , R=2\Omega \;\;Cond...(iii)[/latex] as we know from ABCD parameter, [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]I_1=CV_2-DI_2 [/latex] From condition (i), [latex]10=A(0)-B(4) [/latex] [latex]B=-\frac{10}{4} [/latex] From condition (ii), [latex] 5=A(1.25)-\left ( -\frac{10}{4} \right ) \times 1.25 [/latex] [latex]A=\frac{\left ( 5-\frac{12.5}{4} \right )}{1.25}=1.5 [/latex] From condition (iii), [latex] 3=1.5(2I)-\left ( -\frac{10}{4} \right )\times I [/latex] [latex]3=3I+2.5I [/latex] [latex]I=0.545 A[/latex]

question: Question 47 In the given circuit, the parameter k is positive, and the power dissipated in the 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor is 12.5W. The value of k is _________.
solution: [latex]\Rightarrow \; \frac{V_0^2}{2}=12.5 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_0^2=12.5 \times 2 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_0=5 [/latex] KCL at A, [latex]\Rightarrow \; -2.5-k(5)+5=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; k=\frac{2.5}{5}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A separately excited DC motor runs at 1000 rpm on no load when its armature terminals are connected to a 200V DC source and the rated voltage is applied to the field winding. The armature resistance of this motor is 1[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The no-load armature current is negligible. With the motor developing its full load torque, the armature voltage is set so that the rotor speed is 500 rpm. When the load torque is reduced to 50% of the full load value under the same armature voltage conditions, the speed rises to 520 rpm. Neglecting the rotational losses, the full load armature current (in Ampere) is _______.
solution: [latex]V_t=200V, N=1000 \text{rpm}, I_{a0}=0A\;...(1) [/latex] [latex]V_t=V(say), N=500\text{rpm}, T_d=T_{fL}\;...(2)[/latex] [latex] V_t=V(said),N=520\text{rpm}, [/latex] [latex]T'_L=\frac{T_L}{2}=\frac{T_{FL}}{2}\;\;...(3)[/latex] [latex] P_{lossws}=0 [/latex] [latex]R_a=1\Omega[/latex] From condition (1), [latex]E_b=V_t-I_aR_a [/latex] [latex]E_{b_1}=200V, N=1000\text{rpm} [/latex] Since from (2), [latex]\begin{aligned} N_2 &=500\text{rpm} \\ E_{b_2} &=\frac{500 \times 200}{1000}=100V \\ E_{b_2} &= V-I_{fL}R_a\\ 100 &= V-I_{fL}R_a\\ 100 &= V-I_{fL}\;...(4)\\ & \text{Again (3)},\\ N_3 &= 520 \text{rpm}\\ E_{b_3}&= \frac{520 \times 200}{1000}=104V\\ & \text{as we know}\\ 104&=V-\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\times R \\ &= V-\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\;...(5)\\ &\text{From equation (4) and (5),}\\ 100 + I_{fL}&= 104+\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\\ \text{on solving,} I_{fL}&=8A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A DC motor has the following specifications: 10 hp, 37.5 A, 230 V; flux/pole = 0.01 Wb, number of poles = 4, number of conductors = 666, number of parallel paths = 2. Armature resistance = 0.267 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The armature reaction is negligible and rotational losses are 600 W. The motor operates from a 230 V DC supply. If the motor runs at 1000 rpm, the output torque produced (in Nm) is ___-________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E_b &=\frac{\phi ZNP}{60A} =222V\\ I_a&= \frac{V-E_b}{P_a}\\ &= \frac{230-222}{0.267}\\ &=29.9625A \\ T &=\frac{60}{2\pi (1000)}[222 \times 29.96-600] \\ &= 57.8 N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A 200/400 V, 50 Hz, two-winding transformer is rated at 20 kVA. Its windings are connected as an auto-transformer of rating 200/600 V. A resistive load of 12 [latex]\Omega[/latex] is connected to the high voltage (600 V) side of the auto-transformer. The value of equivalent load resistance (in Ohm) as seen from low voltage side is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} K &=\frac{200}{600}=\frac{1}{3} \\ R_{eq} &=12 \times \frac{1}{9}=1.33\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Two single-phase transformers T1 and T2 each rated at 500 kVA are operated in parallel. Percentage impedances of T1 and T2 are (1 + j6) and (0.8 + j4.8), respectively. To share a load of 1000 kVA at 0.8 lagging power factor, the contribution of T2 (in kVA) is ________.

Question 52 In the signal flow diagram given in the figure, [latex]u_{1} \; and \; u_{2}[/latex] are possible inputs whereas [latex]y_{1} \; and \;  y_{2}[/latex] are possible outputs. When would the SISO system derived from this diagram be controllable and observable?
solution: Equations from the flow diagram,[latex]\dot{x}_1=5x_1-2x_2+u_1 [/latex] [latex]y_1=x_1 [/latex] [latex]\dot{x}_2=5x_1+x_2+u_1+u_2 [/latex] [latex]y_2=x_1-x_2 [/latex] [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}x+\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 1& 1 \end{bmatrix}u [/latex] [latex]y=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix}x [/latex] Considering the SISO cases:[/latex] [latex] 1. \;\;u_1(input)[/latex] and [latex] y_1(output):[/latex] [latex] A\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]B\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and  [latex] C=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]O\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} C\\ CA \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 5 & -2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank (O)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;  Observable [/latex] [latex]C\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} B & AB \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &3 \\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; Rank(C)\neq 2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; non-controllable [/latex] [latex]2.\;\;u_2(input) [/latex] and  [latex] y_1(output): [/latex] [latex]A\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]B\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and  [latex] C\triangleq \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]O\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 5 & -2 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank (O)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Observable [/latex] [latex]C\triangleq\begin{bmatrix} 0 &-2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Rank(C)=2[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; controllable [/latex] [latex]3. \;\;u_2(input) [/latex] and [latex] y_2(output) : [/latex] [latex]Rank(O)\neq 2\Rightarrow[/latex] non-observable [latex]Rank(C) =2 \Rightarrow [/latex] controllable [latex]4. \; \; u_1 (input) [/latex] and [latex] y_2(output)[/latex]: non-observale and non-controllable.

options.A: When [latex]u_{1}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{1}[/latex] is the only output
options.B: When [latex]u_{2}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{1}[/latex] is the only output
options.C: When [latex]u_{1}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{2}[/latex] is the only output
options.D: When [latex]u_{2}[/latex] is the only input and [latex]y_{2}[/latex] is the only output

question: Question 53 The transfer function of a second order real system with a perfectly flat magnitude response of unity has a pole at (2-j3). List all the poles and zeroes.
solution: Response of transfer function is unit for all [latex]\omega[/latex]. [latex]M=1; P_1=2-j3[/latex] Second order system, hence number of poles =2 Therefore, second pole [latex] P_2=2+j3[/latex] Now for M=1, and due to x-axis symmetry of root locus of transfer function, position of zeroes must be [latex]Z_1=-2-j3[/latex] and [latex]Z_2=-2+j3[/latex]

options.B: Poles at ([latex]\pm[/latex]2-j3), one zero at origin.

question: Question 54 Find the transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}[/latex] of the system given below.
solution: [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{G_1+G_2}{1-(-G_1H-G_2H)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{G_1+G_2}{1+G_1H+G_2H)}[/latex]

question: Question 55 The open loop poles of a third order unity feedback system are at 0, -1, -2. Let the frequency corresponding to the point where the root locus of the system transits to unstable region be K. Now suppose we introduce a zero in the open loop transfer function at -3, while keeping all the earlier open loop poles intact. Which one of the following is TRUE about the point where the root locus of the modified system transits to unstable region?
solution: [latex]\frac{K(s+3)}{s(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] [latex]P=3, \; Z=1 [/latex] [latex]P-Z=3-1=2[/latex] asymptotes angle [latex]=90^{\circ}, 180^{\circ} [/latex] Centroid [latex]=\frac{(-3)-(-3)}{2}=0[/latex] as root locus never cross asymptotes so, will remain in left sideof x-axis.

options.A: It corresponds to a frequency greater than K
options.B: It corresponds to a frequency less than K
options.C: It corresponds to a frequency K
options.D: Root locus of modified system never transits to unstable region
